title: Between 8 March 2022 and 20 May 2022, will shares of Meta (fka Facebook) close above $238.00 per share?
preds: @ ay left and 15% jump can only happen on unpredictable events

No, I don't think the shares will close above the threshold.

Interestingly, for every day the stock opens at the current price level (~$208), I estimate that it has an approximately 1% chance of closing above $238 for that day. Of course, the stock may not stay at this price level for long, but thought it might be of interest since it indicates that, unless the price starts going higher, the forecast should fall pretty rapidly from today forward. In 10,000 random-walk simulations, the stock crosses the threshold just under 17% of the time based on sampling from a high-volatility period of historical data  (i.e. 2022 price fluctuations). At this point its best chance for a positive resolution would probably be a series of "lucky" days  where the stock jumps a few percentage points and a minimal number of "unlucky" days with the stock falling. Random fluctuations pushing the stock in the "right" direction could yet push it over the threshold.
Stock puked back its gains from yesterday, now 11 days left and needs to go up 14%

I may have read this wrong - a big increase makes the target now look realistic within the remaining two weeks. I'm still slightly sceptical but accept there is now a reasonable likelihood of $238 given the general market shift higher.

Late day surge and now about 7% away with 12 days left... pretty wild, this could end up being the first time I can remember marking something as 0% or 100% and then getting it wrong which would not be great. That said it looks like this surge was riding a 3% overall market surge so FB's increase was less due to FB specific factors this time.

Though everyone loves to hate on Meta, it's still one of the cornerstone tech stocks that institutional investors use.  Given the larger increments of interest rate hikes (like today on 5/4), the market ticks upwards.  So...I suppose I'll circle back on this.  Today Meta trades at $223 and while a 6.7% increase in 2 weeks' time seems unlikely, I think it wouldn't be unreasonable to see the price getting closer...and then setting off a buying spree.
At 223.  Close to the target and volatility is high.
Closed at 223.41 today, moving up some more (+11.34) from recent lows. It has moved up 48.46 in the past 5 trading days. 14.59 more to go to reach 238. 12 more trading days in the forecast period.

There could be another big news cycle to the negative or a major announcement/demo that causes some spike. Dropping from 50% to 30% and will decay linearly until the 20th.

When the stock was around this level 7 trading days ago, I had it 12% odds. We have about 16 trading days left and while the 17% surge is impressive, a similar surge would have to happen again in/over the next three weeks to matter. The reality is that there isn't a second earnings report that is going to drop and save the stock price, and it is highly likely that the Fed will raise interest rates by the largest amount since 2000 next week, supplying further downward stock pressure.  Now - if the Fed surprised everyone and only raised by 0.25% then maybe all bets are off and stocks would soar, but nobody thinks that will happen given statements Powell has made. There's also the fact the volatility is clearly high as hell right now, which maybe suggests I should be more cautious. That said I feel comfortable keeping this very low.

Well, this one has been a bit of a rollercoaster for me. I guess it seems like an appropriate time post-earning to take a lay of the land and forecast this question again.I continue to believe that Meta is pretty drastically oversold when compared to it's Mega-cap tech peers. It continues to be a cashflow generating machine that despite some concerns about it's old namesake product; has been diversifying into a bunch of different products and areas of business for years. (See my initial forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1416352 ) However, up until earnings it appeared that Macro factors caused by Monetary tightening by the FED were leading to compression across the Tech sector as a whole; dragging Meta down with it. (I originally thought that aggressive monetary tightening was already priced into the market after the interest rate hikes at the March meeting. Apparently it was not entirely priced in at that point). I was just about ready to capitulate that these Macro factors would lead to the stock remaining below the threshold beyond the deadline date if earnings resulted in a flat to negative result.However, with the large rebound of the stock after reporting earning, the NASDAQ (At least currently) holding key levels around 12600, and several other large Mega-cap tech companies reporting after the bell today; it seems like we could be primed for a continued dramatic reversal if AAPL and/or AMZN put up big number tonight. (Driving up tech at an index level)Right now FB is sitting at ~$205, needing about ~14% in the next month, and is approaching key price levels around ~$210. If FB is able to overcome this $210 in the next week or so it technically appears to have a lot of room to run to the upside. (I am assuming if it can break back above this level in the next week we are likely to see this resolve as a "Yes") If the NASDAQ rebounds back off it's 12600 level (AAPL and AMZN earning should be a big factor in this) this seems likely to me. If FB rejects this ~$210 level and/or the NASDAQ breaks down below the ~12600 level in the next week than I think this one almost certainly a "No". I do think that the NASDAQ will hold these key levels and rebound, which in turn will drive FB up with it above ~$210 this week. Although, I certainly have been humbled by this question around my certainty of the outcome. I am going to leave a 20% margin of error that the NASDAQ still has another leg down from here.

I think I moved down to the crowd too much (for 4 days only, but still). I could picture this question resolving either way, especially as it only has to happen on some date between now and May 20, not *on* May 20, and right now, the stock is at 203.99.

Apparently Face/Off has been shutting down accounts but not explaining why.  There can be several reasons for this, including that they're not doing this themselves but instead have been hacked.  There are no explanations that cover them in glory, though.  It seems that almost no weeks go by without something stupid or shifty coming out of there.  Sooner or later this is likely to cause some and perhaps many of their adherents to--oh, I don't know--think.   Full disclosure:  I have not been on Facebook for about a decade, and yet manage to keep my photos and documents available and also communicate with Friends-and-Relations.  I don't miss the countless photos of people's lunch or pets.  You might want to try this.

Given the Ukraine/Russia "peace talks" development this AM I believe we are going to see a continued "risk-on" rally which should lead to a push higher for big-tech.

Value dropped off in early Feb 22, but given the way tech companies are going and the fact that Facebook and what’s app are still so prévenant, it’s difficult to see how the stock won’t recover to 238 at least one day before May.

As of writing this forecast FB is sitting at ~$224 having rebounded off it's lows and is continuing a strong move to the upside, needing ~6% more to the upside from here.  I believe there is strong fundamental reason to think this rally should continue (See my initial forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1416352 ) when looking at FB as an individual stock. I also believe at the sector level the NASDAQ bottomed on March 14th(See my second forecast https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1419031 ) with fear of a taper tantrum caused by the FED beginning rate liftoff and the hight of fear surrounding the initial invasion of Ukraine reaching a fever pitch. The initial rate hikes came and went without the tantrum and the market digested that the Ukrainian crisis is likely to be a more ongoing crisis without immediate implication for Mega-cap tech companies. As such we have had the beginning of a relief rally. To add to all of this when digging into some of the technicals of the market we can see that FB is currently sitting at a 30 day implied volatility of 39.2% when looking at options contracts with a put-to-call ratio sitting at 0.35. (https://volafy.net/equity/FB ) This would indicate that we should expect larger than average moves in the price in the coming weeks (at least until current contracts expire) with the bulls outweighing the bears. To add to this FB has broken above it's 1st SMA, with plenty of room to the upside to retrace back to the 2nd and 3rd SMAs. From a technical standpoint if the stock is able to brake $225 it should easily pass $238 before the deadline. (I will note, I am a little sceptical of relying too much on technical analysis as it can feel a bit too much like a soft science for my liking, but I have found it very useful for trying to predict short term moves when combined with fundamentals.) I think 100% is probably having a bit too much faith in what I see. But as I see it, it is almost impossible for the stock to not hit the threshold price at least for a day before May 20th. There are too many tail winds pushing the price upwards.

I've changed my view on this question quite a lot. $238 was the level at which the last crash in price essentially slowed. It's drifted from there but I suspect the price is now more at the will of the wider market. 57 days between now and the resolution. In the last 7 we have seen enough volatility to push the price of the stock up from 186 to 213. I don't think we need to see a general sustained upward trend in stocks to necessarily reach the $238. I'm essentially reversing my postion here to say I think that in 57 days this is really very likely to happen. To add to this, my initial analysis was based on difference between prices at set intervals, whereas my new understanding of the quesiton is that if the closing price is above the level at any point in the timeframe, this resolves as yes.

Without splitting, I'd say unlikely, roughly 20%. Splitting would make it a bit more unlikely, maybe 5%. Splitting (within the coming 2 months) itself (with my limited knowledge of stocks) seems unlikely too, since the stock price is so low. So the change due to splitting seems insignificant.

As I mentioned in my response to @slapthepancake [1],  there was an issue with my original Monte Carlo simulation implementation that biased the results toward a higher likelihood of having a closing day above $238. The problem was that, when i wrote the simulator, it was geared toward predicting crypto prices (which trade every day). FB only has 5 trading days per week (and fewer on weeks with holidays) and therefore has fewer opportunities to close above $238.00 than the original simulation suggested. I made a crude modification to the simulator to reduce the trading days to 5/7 of the days left and came back with 42.46%. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1420124

I think I trust the @JonathanMann Monte Carlo more than the options market that's been informing my prior forecasts, options market puts it at ~28% vs. 51% from the Monte Carlo. Getting probability from IV assumes the option price was determined anticipating normally distributed volatility, but that probably doesn't apply if the stock just tanked like FB did. There's probably a wider range of higher values it could hit than lower ones just given its price history, so I'm not sure the IV-to-probability calculation works well here.  The Monte Carlo I'm running also removes the -26% shift and gets a probability of 48%, slightly lower than the 51%. https://github.com/gjusticea/forecast-tools/blob/master/Monte%20Carlo%20Sim.R

Some recovery for growth stocks in the past few days, and looking from here, a +6.7% move doesn't seem out of question with the high volatility we've been seeing, and the March FOMC meeting behind us.

As of making this update FB has rebounded off it's bottom and is sitting at ~$215 currently. To hit the threshold we need a ~9.7% increase in 2 months, or an average of ~4.8% upside a month. Well within reason if this NASDAQ relief rally continues. (An added note, recent volatility also increases the chance of a spike to the upside caused by derivative traders. Even if followed by a move to the downside the stock just needs to close above the threshold for one day.) It appears to me the bottom is in on this NASDAQ Bear market, and the relief rally appears to have kicked off. This should serve as a rising tide to a stock that I already see as having significant idiosyncratic upside potential. (See my initial forecast if you are interested) I am leaving a 15% chance this is a Bull trap and we see the NASDAQ bear market continue, but if there is follow through on this move next week I expect to see it hit the threshold sooner rather than later.

The stock price has climbed 2.08% today so far and is now at $212.06, up from $187.03 at the start of the week, as the market as a whole moved up. That's a +$25.03 move this week (so far, with more than half a day left to go), with only $25.94 left to go to reach $238. Reaching $238 even next week is not inconceivable. Regardless of what's happening with the company, all else considered, if the whole market moves up, Meta will move with it. And I do think the market is likely to continue moving up, as the news about Ukraine improves and inflation remains high.
Price target currently 321.  Rebounding from its all time low.  Q report in end of April will influence.

Meta’s share price dropped on 02FEB due to projections of reduced 1st Quarter results (https://variety.com/2022/digital/news/facebook-meta-q4-2021-earnings-1235170176/). I believe 1st Quarter earnings publish in April. Second quarter results won’t publish until July. While Meta’s stock price was higher than 238 a share prior to 02FEB, it has been declining since (https://www.google.com/search?q=meta+share+price). Really it has been declining since January. The release of reduced earnings will either allow the price to decline more or will remain the same. Either way, it seems unlikely that the share price will rebound. Of the 119 months Facebook has been publicly traded, it has only been above 238 on 20 occasions (17%). But the current decline probably means the chances of a rebound are unlikely. Despite the Spring to Summer 2020 dip and recovery.
Just over $30/share more to go, halfway up from its recent bottom. It may get carried up with the market.

Shareholder confidence has been sustainably weakened since the latest drop-off. Greater market sentiment in the tech sector has helped the price a bit recently, but a price level of around 237/238 remains a technical barrier.

Facebook has never had a stock split since going public, meaning the outside view suggests against that happening. Facebook crossed the $238 threshold in summer of 2020 and has been above that level until the last month. The war makes more volatility likely in the next few months and strong returns seem unlikely. I think the chances are fairly low. https://seekingalpha.com/article/4451402-will-facebook-stock-ever-split

Initial forecast 3/17:  Rough estimate based on a look at previous data.  Price would need to increase at least 13%+ based on current price.  That type of increase has occurred in the past but overall market is down right now and Facebook is also dealing with its withdraw from Russia and the loss of $500B since becoming Meta.  Public interest in the metaverse doesn't seem particularly strong right now, so I'm not sure what they could do that would cause much of a rise in their stock price.
I don't think the sentiment toward Meta is likely to change soon.

Historical volatility based estimate gave a 19% chance. I toyed with shaving a couple of points off since they got kicked out of Russia and responded by allowing calls for violence on their platform.  Neither of those seem great for an advertising business but I decided I don't really know the situation well enough to do better than the market's current estimates of price and uncertainty. Note to future me - remember that this question ignores splits.  I don't think one would be coming with a falling share price but I haven't really looked into it.

@ifrancis had some good points below that I'm incorporating. Same with @steven_meyer er. Generally, it's a substantial move for the stock to make in a short period of time. If I had the numbers at my disposal I'd try to find out how often FB shares have made a ~15-20% move in a two month time frame. Given the shares have been quite oversold on the back of their last earnings and the general growth->value transition, I wouldn't be surprised to see a "catch-up" trade if we do get a risk-on environment. Given the macro (war, rising rates, growth->value rotation, anti-tech sentiment, earnings risk for FB) I do lean to a "NO" scenario. That said, given the market volatility and how oversold tech has gotten this year, maybe the first rate hike and expectation of liftoff from the Fed is priced in and we'll see a counter-trend bounce that pushes FB above the $238 price.

Given that Meta shares were above $238 for most of the past year, this would seem possible. Inflation is likely to push stock prices up in general, too. However, some reasons for the recent fall in Meta's stock price seem likely to persist in the forecast period (e.g., Apple privacy changes). And I don't know how much of their revenue was from Russia, but that'll largely be gone probably for quite a while. A potentially big move in share price could come after the next quarterly earnings report in early May, but other events could also affect the price as well, of course. But a 24% increase from today's price would seem somewhat unlikely in the forecast period, as the forces that brought the stock to its current price will likely persist and dominate its price in the forecast period.
Another factor to consider, though, is that this question asks whether the share price will close above $238 on *any* day between March 8 and May 20. Given the volatility of this stock, I think there's a considerable chance that this could happen. Also, it has only been below $238 most recently since the Q4 2021 earnings report was released. If the Q1 2022 earnings report is rosier, share prices could just as easily rise again.
https://www.cnbc.com/2022/02/03/facebook-shares-plummet-22percent-after-reporting-weak-guidance.html

Business model pressured due to changes in privacy measures, little perceived ability to grow through acquisition as Big Tech in the cross hairs of both major US political parties. Metaverse opportunity represents the type of pot of gold over the rainbow opportunity that investors are increasingly disinterested in owning as they weigh macro-economic regime change, tightening at the fed, higher equity risk premiums, and volatile markets.
Very high stock specific volatility, and outlook for FB not so hot given recent Apple privacy policy changes.  Of course that is baked into the stock price.
My initial forecast was not aggressive enough

With the current share price of: 192.01, that's a 23.9% gain. Definitely doable, especially if stocks recover in a big way and the Russian invasion of Ukraine starts to suddenly fade. However, that's not particularly likely, and Facebook has it's own firm-specific problems lately. I'll be very interested in how the next week or so goes, but I'm hard pressed to see many paths towards this resolving "yes".

As of this forecast FB is sitting at ~$192 per share, after falling ~50% from ATH. Recovering to $238 would represent a ~20% increase in the next 2 months or 10% increase per month. This is a significant increase, but 10% monthly increases are by no means unheard of for FB, we see many examples in the Post COVID recovery period. FBs most recent pull back can -- in my opinion -- mainly be attributed to a combination of forecasts of declining growth in their old namesake product, issues with targeted advertising as the resulting from iOS changes, the rise of Tik Tok, uncertainty around the companies name change and direction of the company going froward, recent questions around ethics and business practices, and a general market trend away from growth and tech and into value. While these are legitimate concerns, I think the stock has been far too oversold. Ultimately this is a company that still has a massive source of revenue that it is able to funnel back into R&D to fund just about whatever ambitions it has. Also, while a lot of emphasis has been put on the future prospects for it's old name sake product, I think it is overlook how many other things this company has been working on for years. Even outside of well known assets like Messenger, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Oculus. They have made massive inroads in e-commerce space helping sellers with direct sales through FB and Insta, extensive work on advanced AI (can be seen with their automatic post translations, Spanish to english is particularly good), are one of the first companies to put out a pair of AR glasses in the Ray-Band Stories, have been making gaming acquisitions all over the place since 2020, support one of the largest backend infrastructures that could be used to spun out into an AWS type hosting service if they so desired, and still has one of the larger and more talented employee pools out there. Ultimately, Meta is not just Facebook. It hasn't been for a long time; even before the name change. I think recent moves put too much emphasis on risks to their old name sake product, and undervalue the rest of the company. If there is reversal in tech at an index level, I would expect FB to get bought up hand over fist as it will be seen as incredible value compared to it's Mega-cap peers. The question will just be if this value is seen enough by May 20th to get back about $238. I think in that short of a timeframe I see it as a bit of a tossup, but I will lean toward yes because I truly do see the value there.

Implied volatility on call options for FB for May 20 are ~45%, currently at $192.03 with 66 days remaining, that puts us at 13% chance.  Bumping a smidge higher right now, just giving them the more generous implied volatility of 50%. Their earnings report will come out in late April and I haven't read anything optimistic about it, they tanked because they forecasted lower earnings on it and I'm inclined to believe them. However, $238 was the price they dipped to after that announcement, and they've kept declining since, so its possible that their earnings coming in as bad as expected instead of worse will lift them back up to that level, or beating it will look better. Their analyst ratings are mostly buys, and $238 is pretty low for them historically. All that said I still would never buy it, their name change reads as a gimmick that acknowledges the decline of their core business, and privacy initiatives throughout the rest of the sector are having a clear impact already. But even if the company is hot garbage, volatility around earnings and expectations still can push it above $238. https://www.optionstrategist.com/calculators/probability
Seems improbable  but a new innovation/ post-conflict hysterical bump in share prices are plausible but unlikely scenarios
